awd_titl_txt: HDR Tripods: Texas A&M Research Institute for Foundations of Interdisciplinary Data Science (FIDS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Data Science is rapidly evolving as an essential interdisciplinary field, where advances often result from a combination of ideas from several disciplines.  New types of data have emerged and present tremendous complexities and challenges that require a novel way of interdisciplinary thinking.  The Texas A&M Research Institute for Foundations of Interdisciplinary Data Science (FIDS) will bring together researchers from five disciplinary areas, Statistics, Electrical Engineering,  Mathematics, Computer Science and Industrial Engineering, to conduct research on the foundations of data science motivated by problems arising in bioinformatics, the energy arena, power systems, and transportation systems. The Institute for Foundations of Interdisciplinary Data Science will be well-positioned to develop rigorous theories, novel methodologies, and efficient computational techniques to solve data challenges in many application domains.

Modern large datasets are extremely complex and finding answers to seemingly simple questions often turns into an intractable problem. To address these challenges, FIDS will advance the foundations of data science through research on modeling complex data and developing related theory and algorithms. Development of efficient methods to identify low-dimensional structures in these high-dimensional complex data will be the key strategy to recovering high-dimensional signals with related uncertainties. Novel data-analysis models and algorithms will be developed for representation learning, information extraction, and knowledge discovery from complex data to enable better decision making.  To complement the research effort, FIDS will educate and train students and postdoctoral fellows in areas at the interface of engineering, mathematics, and statistics.  Targeted outreach programs will be developed to increase the pool of women and underrepresented minorities who pursue data-science careers.  An external engagement program will be designed to facilitate collaborations with domain scientists and external data scientists.   These programs will help to develop the intellectual foundation for a new generation of scientists poised to make novel breakthroughs in this exciting new field.

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Data Science is transforming our understanding and operations of all areas of society. The combination of ubiquitous network connectivity, powerful mobile computing devices, remote sensors andcameras, accurate location data, massive data-center resources, and commercial advertising incentives has spurred an astonishing growth inthe collection and availability of data. Data analytics affects political contests, product sales, public opinion, and scientific research. Data now determines how we test for cancers, how much we pay for insurance, and how we shop for cars. Data have created advertisements that follow a person from site to site on the Internetand industrial machines that monitor their own health and requestservice when needed. Rarely has a single technological phenomenon hadsuch widespread impact on society.
The growing role of data has emerged through convergence of a set of distinct trends. Advances in networks created our connected society. Decreases in the cost of computing and storage made large data centers economically viable. The flexibility of the smart-phone “app”architecture unleashed creative and economic opportunities for software developers. Low-cost mobile sensors such as GPS devices, fitness trackers, altimeters, accelerometers, high-resolution cameras, and thermal imagers, record large volumes of data. Digital signalprocessing techniques extract information from this sensor data andmodern statistics and mathematics help software make sense of it  Cloud-based storage systems facilitate collection, consolidation,and sharing of data. Developments in high-performance computing andgrid computing in prior decades paved the way for cloud computing andmodern data centers. The data era grew, almost organically, from the relentless march of digital technology and its application to both scientific research and commercial prosperity.

Our TRIPODS  Institute  Foundations of Interdisciplinary Data Science (FIDS) brought together Texas A&M researchers across computer science, mathematics,electrical engineering and statistics to advance the foundations of Data Science by performing research on algorithms, computation, and statistical learning. The overarching goal was  to develop expertise and build capacity in research, industry and domain-science engagement, and work force development.

We  conduct research and build capacity in the algorithmic foundations of data-science focused on algorithms, computation, and learning with the aim to develop new algorithms for representation learning, information extraction and knowledge discovery from complex data for better decision making. We integrated mathematical approximation theory, Statistical Bayesian theory and engineering control theory to solve data scientific problems like signal processing, deep neural networks, graphical model, data based sequential decisions making etc.. with applications in Bioinformatics, energy, material discovery and more. We wrote 65 published research papers and another 10 papers have been submitted. Our resaerchers presented these research in different prestigious conferences. 

We Ddveloped capacity in education and outreach to help  partners prepare students, postdocs, and professionals to enter the data-science workforce, and create programs and materials to train students. We trained 5 postdoctorate fellows who are plac d in tenure track positions in prestigious institutes like Purdue, University of Delware. We trained graduate students whi received awards for their research.

We Built program capacity in industrial engagement that  helped researchers to establish working relationships and collaborations with both domain scientists and industrial data scientists, for the express purposes of broadening the impact of research and bringing outside perspectives and expertise into the community. Our researchers worked with Material scientists to create new magtefrials, bioinfomatics researchers to create cancer drug and power engineers to create power grids. 

We strengthened partnerships  among organizations and disciplines and that way it  supported world-leading research, education, and  outreach on the foundations and applications of data-science.
